channel.title: Databricks on Afrikaniz3D Blogfolio
channel.description: Recent content in Databricks on Afrikaniz3D Blogfolio

item.title: MTA Post-Covid Recovery Dashboard
item.description:
DESCRIPTION Investigating an MTA ridership dataset to gain insight on the post-covid recovery trends of its various modes of public travel
TOOLS Databricks SQL, RStudio, Shiny, Blender 3D
PROJECT_TYPE Data cleaning, Data manipulation, Data analysis, Data visualization, Trend Analysis, Shiny dashboard development
LINKS Maven Commuter Challenge, Dashboard, Github Repo

item.title: Split-Push
item.description:
I slowed down on the job searching last year after 100s of applications and seeing posts from creators like Jim Chuong. When you also have to deal with things like ghost job postings, and some instances of postings being for something else altogether, You really do need a different strategy when networking isn’t as easy and it’s an industry you’re fairly new in.

This is now the sixth year I’ve been a creator posting to social media. Although the bulk of that has been as a 3D designer, I’m slowly finding gaps for me to marry the two so that the codeswitch doesn’t feel as jarring. I alluded to this in the last blog and it turns out it’s related to Cognitive Load Theory with some Neuroplasticity. It really explains why I got so little else done on the days I set aside to work on data projects - the brain was tapped-out. A lot of it, I think, was also related to me still trying to wrap my head around the new problems coupled with starting with templates that were too complicated for someone unfamiliar.

item.title: Healthier Candy Choices for the Maven Halloween Challenge
item.description: I already had an angle for where I wanted to take this project prior to looking at the data. The goal was to prioritize choosing the the healthier options coupled with them being the most popular according to respondent feedback - really simple, to the point where there were times I felt I was doing a disservice to the project and the data. I always find something an any EDA I do that has little to do with the outlined question but is still significant in some way. In this particular project I found that there were a number of name/ownership changes and some treats were even discontinued. This was possible because a lot of the work for this project happened outside the table due to the need for additional information.

item.title: Lobbyists 4 America
item.description:
![][1]
 

DESCRIPTION Investigating an Massachussetts General Hospital (MGH)
TOOLS Databricks SQL, Python
PROJECT_TYPE Data cleaning, Machine Learning, Textual Analysis, Sentiment Analysis, Data analysis, Data visualization
LINKS Maven Commuter Challenge, Dashboard

 
As part of getting the SQL for Data Science certification, I was required to complete a capstone project. I chose the Lobbyists 4 America project. The project was done on the Community Edition of the Databricks platform. I used both SQL and Python to carry out the exercise.

item.title: Maven Hospital Challenge
item.description:
![][1]
 

DESCRIPTION Investigating an Massachussetts General Hospital (MGH)
TOOLS Databricks SQL
PROJECT_TYPE Data cleaning, Data analysis, Data visualization
LINKS Maven Commuter Challenge, Dashboard

 

I took part in this year’s Maven Hospital Challenge. I used Databrick’s Community Edition. The exploration was mostly SQL-based. I opted for Databricks over Big Query for the ability to upload large files.
